newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: FORECAST - ING year net seen up 22 pct.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - ING year net seen up 22 pct.

text.p: Dutch financial services group Internationale Nederlanden Groep NV is expected to announce an about 22 percent increase in 1996 net profit on Thursday, analysts said.
Analysts polled by Reuters expect net profits before preference dividends of between 3.17 billion and 3.36 billion guilders, averaging 3.22 billion, up from 2.65 billion in 1995.
They expect banking to have outstripped insurance for profit growth as buoyant markets boosted commission and trading income and investment bank Barings improved its contribution.
"We expect them to be good numbers," Salomon Brothers analyst Matthew Czepliewicz said.
ING will also unveil its hidden reserves for the first time on Thursday, with forecasts ranging between 2.5 billion and 3.0 billion guilders.
After the first nine months of 1996, ING's net profit had risen 24.1 percent to 2.34 billion guilders.
Czepliewicz said the fourth quarter of last year was good for banks involved in trading and, although ING was not a major trading house, its operations in emerging markets had done well.
Andrew Goodwin of UBS said insurance would have outshone banking for profit growth in the final quarter because banking profits were strong in the last three months of 1995.
Others agreed, citing strong final quarter results from Dutch insurers Aegon and Fortis Amev.
F. van Lanschot Bankiers analyst Jean-Paul van Bavel said the final quarter results would have benefited from a stronger guilder and a continued improvement from non-life insurance.
Bart van der Feen of IRIS Research expected ING's banking profits to have grown 25 percent in 1996 with insurance profits up 16 percent up the previous year.
Within banking, he forecast increases of 14 percent in net interest income, 35 percent in commission income and 18 percent in other income, including trading income.
Van der Feen expected Barings, bought for 1.7 billion guilders in March 1995 after it collapsed from derivatives trading losses, to have just covered its interest costs.
Van Bavel said: "But it's still disappointing and not generating the profits they would have expected when they took it over."
Tom Bennett of Paribas expected ING to have smoothed profits by making extra provisions in the fourth quarter for computer projects associated with the euro currency and the millennium.
The group set aside 275 million guilders in the first nine months of the year for these projects.
"They should have had a stunning year of trading but they're in the process of hiding it away one way or the other," Bennett said.
In insurance, he said the Dutch life operations would have lifted profits due mainly to premium growth but he expected losses from the greenfields operations around the world.
